H0.text: who is hammurabi and what did he do. Lawgiver

H1.text: who is hammurabi and what did he do. Emperor

H2.text: who is hammurabi and what did he do. Judge

H3.text: who is hammurabi and what did he do. Monarch

A4.text: He was best known for having issued his eponymous code, which he claimed to have received from Shamash, the Babylonian god of justice.

A5.text: Hammurabi was the sixth Amorite king of the Old Babylonian Empire, reigning from c. 1792 to c. 1750 BC.

A6.text: By codifying laws and making them public, Hammurabi established a system that would influence generations so that the principles of justice, fairness, and accountability that underpin the Code continue to resonate today.

A7.text: He secured Babylonian dominance over the Mesopotamian plain through military prowess, diplomacy, and treachery.

A8.text: Hammurabi forced their successor Mut-Ashkur to pay tribute to Babylon c. 1751 BC, giving Babylonia control over Assyria's centuries-old Hattian and Hurrian colonies in Anatolia.

A9.text: He established a bureaucracy, with taxation and centralized government.
